title: 13.28 — Girth measurements (sites + setup)
summary: Equipment: flexible spring-loaded tape measure (e.g., Gulick tape).
Personnel: one tester + one recorder.
Standardize body position (relaxed anatomical position unless otherwise specified).
Sites shown include chest, upper arm, forearm, waist (abdomen), hips (buttocks), thigh, calf.
Measure at maximal circumference where indicated (e.g., upper arm/forearm/calf/thigh) and at defined landmarks for waist/hips/chest.
notes: If you want this as a drill later, we can generate MCQ like: 'Which site is measured at the umbilicus level?' etc.

title: 13.27 — Skinfold measurements (equipment + how to take a skinfold)
summary: Equipment: skinfold calipers, flexible tape measure, marking pen.
Personnel: one tester + one recorder.
Take measures on dry skin (ideally before exercise) to improve reliability.
Pinch a fold of skin + subcutaneous fat; place caliper jaws perpendicular to the fold near the pinch; release pressure and read after a short delay; record consistently.
Use the selected site/equation set appropriate to the population; repeat trials and average if within tolerance.
notes: This is best as a reference card + later drills for: site identification, fold orientation (vertical/diagonal), and key reliability rules.

title: 13.26 — Overhead squat (flexibility/movement screen)
summary: Equipment: dowel (or barbell). Personnel: one tester/recorder.
Setup: arms overhead (shoulders flexed), elbows locked; grip ~2x shoulder width; stance ~shoulder width with toes forward/slightly out.
Movement: squat down under control while keeping heels down and torso as upright as possible; depth goal is hips below top of knee crease if possible.
Perform multiple reps; assessment is qualitative (pass/fail style), best done after warm-up/familiarization.
notes: Later we can add a checklist-style scoring UI (e.g., heel lift, knee valgus, torso angle) rather than MCQ.

title: 13.25 — Sit-and-reach test (procedure)
summary: Keep the method consistent across testing sessions (same measuring setup each time).
Warm up first with light movement + dynamic stretching.
Seated position with legs straight; reach forward with both hands together, slow and controlled.
Record best of multiple trials using the same measurement scale/zero point each time.
notes: We can later turn this into a mini 'protocol quiz' (e.g., what to standardize, how to score, what invalidates a trial).

title: 13.23 — Balance Error Scoring System (BESS)
summary: Equipment: foam balance pad + stopwatch. Personnel: timer/recorder.
Stances typically include double-leg, single-leg (non-dominant), and tandem; performed on firm and foam surfaces.
Each condition lasts a fixed time with hands on hips and eyes closed (per protocol).
Score is total 'errors' across conditions (e.g., opening eyes, lifting hands, stepping, stumbling, hip > 30° flex/abd, out of position for >5s).
Sum errors across conditions for a total score.
notes: This is a perfect candidate for a 'checklist scoring' tool later (tap-to-add errors).

title: 13.24 — Star Excursion Balance Test (SEBT) directions + procedure
summary: Athlete stands on one leg at the center; reaches the free leg along taped lines (multiple directions) as far as possible while maintaining control.
Measure reach distance; perform multiple trials and average per direction/leg per protocol.
Standardize start/return control and invalid trials (e.g., loss of balance, failure to return to start under control, failure to touch/maintain rules).
Often, a subset of directions (anteromedial/medial/posteromedial) is used in practice depending on needs.
notes: Later we can add a mini data-entry calculator: limb length normalization and composite scoring if you want it.
